topic.shortdesc: Merges one or more incremental backups together.

section.title: Description
section.p: Merging incremental backups allows you to free up disk space on the machine that your backup archive is located by de-duplicating similar data between backups. It also also allows you to avoid having to run full backups in favor of continuous incremental backups. This can significantly reduce the amount of time you spend backing up your cluster. To merge backups you just need to specify the starting and ending backups that you would like to merge. The current backup names can be found by running the list command on your backup archive.

The merge command works by first copying the oldest backup to be merged to a special .merge directory. Data from each subsequent incremental backup directory which is part of the merge is then copied into this directory. Once all of the data has been merged into the .merge directory the old backups are deleted from the backup archive and the .merge directory is renamed to the backup specified in the --end argument. Merging backups is also fault tolerant so it is not possible for there to be data loss even if the backup tool crashes. To ensure that this is the case there is a .merge_status file which records the last completed step of the merge and which incremental backups are supposed to be merged. If a merge fails to complete then the backup tool will detect that there is an incomplete merge and will revert the merge.

Since the merge command does not delete any files from the backup archive until it is finished merging all of the data together you need to make sure that there is free disk space at least equal to the size of all incremental backups that are being merged.

section.title: Options
section.p:
The following are the command options:
merge options
Option Description
--dir /[directory name] Name of the backup directory.
--name REPOSITORY-NAME Name of the backup repository.
--start [backup timestamp] Timestamp of the first backup from which to merge.
--end [backup timestamp] Timestamp of the last backup through which to merge.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Run the merge command to merge backups together, starting and ending with the specified backup timestamps:./backup merge --dir /tmp/backups --name travel --start 2016-01-22T15:42:41.383468246-08:00 \ --end 2016-01-22T15:42:41.383468246-08:00
